source.raw_text:
Sandbag box squats work your quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, and posterior chain, with added demands on your upper back, forearms, and biceps due to stabilizing the shifting sandbag. The movement pattern involves sitting back onto a box (like a chair), activating hip hinges for posterior chain strength, and then exploding up, improving power and functional strength by mimicking real-world lifting of bulky items. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Legs): Quadriceps, Glutes, Hamstrings, Adductors (inner thighs). 
• Stabilizers & Support: 

    • Core: Abs, obliques, and spinal erectors (lower back) to keep your torso upright. 
    • Upper Back: To maintain posture and control the weight. 
    • Forearms & Biceps: For grip strength to hold the unstable sandbag. 
    • Calves: To stabilize the lower leg. [1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Patterns & Benefits 

• Hip Hinge: Sitting back onto the box emphasizes hip movement, activating the glutes and hamstrings more than a traditional squat. 
• Posterior Chain Focus: Excellent for building strength in the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back (the backside of your body). 
• Strength-Endurance: High reps build significant muscular endurance and systemic strength, transferring to other movements. 
• Functional Strength: The unstable nature of the sandbag mimics lifting heavy, awkward objects (like a box or bag of soil), improving real-world lifting ability. 
• Power Development: The brief pause (or relaxation) on the box allows for a powerful concentric (pushing up) phase, building explosive power. 
• Core & Grip Challenge: The shifting weight constantly engages your core and grip, making it a comprehensive full-body exercise. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9]
